questions.text: Most common source of infection of masticator space is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The masticator space is a deep fascial space in the head and neck region that contains the muscles of mastication (masseter, temporalis, medial, and lateral pterygoids), branches of the mandibular nerve, and vascular structures. Infections of the masticator space usually arise from dental sources, with the third molar (wisdom tooth) being the most common culprit due to its anatomical location and high susceptibility to pericoronitis and deep infections. The third molars (C) are located posteriorly in the mandible and have a close anatomical relationship with the masticator space. Infection from an impacted or abscessed third molar can easily spread into this space, leading to trismus (difficulty opening the mouth), swelling, and pain. Incorrect Options: Option (A) First Molar The first molar is anterior to the third molar and is less likely to directly communicate with the masticator space. Infections here are more commonly associated with submandibular or buccal space infections rather than the masticator space. Option (B) Second Molar While the second molar is closer to the masticator space than the first molar, its infections more commonly involve the buccal and submandibular spaces rather than the masticator space. The third molar, being the most posterior, has a higher risk of spreading infection to the masticator space. Option (D) Second Premolar The second premolar is located even more anteriorly than the molars. Infections originating from the second premolar typically involve buccal space infections or the canine space, not the masticator space.

questions.text: Infection of post-styloid compartment of parapharyngeal space spares :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The parapharyngeal space (PPS) is divided into two compartments: Pre-styloid compartment – contains the deep lobe of the parotid gland, fat, and lymph nodes. Post-styloid compartment – contains the carotid sheath (internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein, CN IX, CN X, CN XI, and CN XII) along with the sympathetic chain. Infections in the post-styloid compartment can affect the cranial nerves within the carotid sheath (IX, X, XI, and XII) but typically spare the facial nerve (CN VII) because it lies outside this compartment, mainly running within the parotid gland and emerging through the stylomastoid foramen. Incorrect Options: Option (A) CN IX (Glossopharyngeal Nerve) The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) runs within the carotid sheath in the post-styloid compartment and is commonly affected by infections in this space. Involvement can cause dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) and loss of sensation in the posterior third of the tongue and pharynx. Option (B) CN X (Vagus Nerve) The vagus nerve (CN X) is also within the carotid sheath and is frequently involved in post-styloid infections. Damage can result in hoarseness (due to recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement) and autonomic dysfunction. Option (C) CN XI (Accessory Nerve) The accessory nerve (CN XI) is also part of the carotid sheath and can be affected in a post-styloid compartment infection. This can lead to weakness in the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles, causing difficulty in turning the head and shoulder drooping.

questions.text: Swelling between tonsillar area and superior constrictor muscle is knows as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A swelling between the tonsillar area and the superior constrictor muscle is called quinsy (peritonsillar abscess). This condition occurs due to pus collection in the peritonsillar space, usually as a complication of acute tonsillitis. Patients present with fever, severe throat pain (unilateral), muffled voice ("hot potato voice"), trismus (difficulty opening the mouth), and uvular deviation away from the affected side. Incorrect Options: Option (B) Dental Abscess: A dental abscess originates from infection of the teeth or gums, commonly due to dental caries or periodontal disease. It is localized around the tooth root and does not involve the peritonsillar or pharyngeal spaces. It may lead to submandibular or masticator space infections, but it does not cause swelling between the tonsillar area and superior constrictor muscle. Option (C) Parapharyngeal Abscess: A parapharyngeal abscess occurs lateral to the superior constrictor muscle, in the parapharyngeal space, and is usually secondary to tonsillitis, pharyngitis, or dental infections. It presents with neck swelling, trismus, dysphagia, and respiratory distress in severe cases, but it is not confined to the peritonsillar region. Option (D) Retropharyngeal Abscess: A retropharyngeal abscess occurs in the retropharyngeal space (behind the pharynx, between the prevertebral fascia and the buccopharyngeal fascia). It is common in children under 5 years and can lead to stridor, respiratory distress, dysphagia, and fever. It does not cause localized swelling between the tonsillar area and superior constrictor muscle.

questions.text: A post dental extraction patient presents with swelling in posterior one third of the sternocliedomastoid, the tonsil is pushed medially. Most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A parapharyngeal abscess is the most likely diagnosis in a post-dental extraction patient presenting with swelling in the posterior third of the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) and medial displacement of the tonsil. The parapharyngeal space is located lateral to the superior pharyngeal constrictor and can be divided into: Anterior compartment (contains muscles and lymph nodes) Posterior compartment (contains cranial nerves IX, X, XI, XII, and the carotid artery) Post-dental extraction infections can spread to the parapharyngeal space, leading to trismus, fever, neck swelling, medial displacement of the tonsil, and difficulty swallowing. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Retropharyngeal Abscess: A retropharyngeal abscess is located behind the pharynx, between the buccopharyngeal fascia and prevertebral fascia. It typically presents with bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall, dysphagia, and respiratory distress, rather than swelling in the posterior third of SCM or medial displacement of the tonsil. Option (C) Ludwig’s Angina: Ludwig’s angina is a rapidly progressing cellulitis of the submandibular, sublingual, and submental spaces. It presents with bilateral floor-of-mouth swelling, tongue elevation, difficulty breathing, and trismus, but does not cause tonsillar displacement. Unlike a parapharyngeal abscess, Ludwig’s angina is not a localized abscess but a diffuse, firm swelling. Option (D) Vincent’s Angina: Vincent’s angina (Trench mouth) is an acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis caused by Fusobacterium and spirochetes. It presents with painful ulceration of the gums, halitosis, and fever, but does not cause significant neck swelling or tonsillar displacement.

questions.text: Most common cause of acute retropharyngeal abscess in children is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The most common cause of acute retropharyngeal abscess in children is adenoid infection (Adenoiditis). The retropharyngeal space contains lymph nodes (Nodes of Rouvière), which drain infections from the nasopharynx, adenoids, and middle ear. Children (especially under 5 years) are prone to retropharyngeal abscesses because these lymph nodes are prominent in early childhood but regress by age 6. Adenoiditis or upper respiratory infections (URIs) can lead to suppuration of these lymph nodes, forming an abscess. Incorrect Options: Option (B) Trauma: Penetrating trauma (e.g., foreign bodies like fish bones or endoscopic procedures) can cause a retropharyngeal abscess, but it is not the most common cause in children. More often seen in adults or older children with a history of ingesting sharp objects. Option (C) Tuberculosis (TB): Tuberculous retropharyngeal abscess (a cold abscess) is seen in developing countries but is chronic and more common in older children and adults. It is not the leading cause of acute retropharyngeal abscess in children. Option (D) Quinsy (Peritonsillar Abscess): Quinsy is a peritonsillar abscess, which is different from a retropharyngeal abscess. It occurs due to tonsillitis complications, not adenoid infections. It is more common in adolescents and adults than young children.

questions.text: 50 yrs old male presented with odynophagia, “hot potato” voice and stridor. On examination diffuse swelling over the posterior pharyngeal wall was seen. X-ray revealed increased retropharyngeal space.Most suspected diagnosis is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most likely diagnosis in a 50-year-old male with odynophagia, "hot potato" voice, stridor, and diffuse swelling over the posterior pharyngeal wall is a prevertebral abscess (Correct Answer: B). Prevertebral abscess is an infection in the prevertebral space, which lies behind the retropharyngeal space and extends from the skull base to the coccyx. X-ray findings of increased retropharyngeal space suggest deep neck space infection, but a prevertebral abscess specifically causes diffuse posterior pharyngeal wall swelling. Severe symptoms like stridor, hot potato voice, and dysphagia indicate airway compromise, a characteristic feature of deep neck infections. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Retropharyngeal Abscess: A retropharyngeal abscess (RPA) is more common in children due to lymphatic drainage patterns. In adults, RPA usually arises from tuberculosis, trauma, or dental infections. Unlike a prevertebral abscess, retropharyngeal abscess does not cause diffuse posterior pharyngeal wall swelling. Option (C) Parapharyngeal Abscess: A parapharyngeal abscess is lateral rather than posterior, presenting with bulging of the lateral pharyngeal wall and displacement of the tonsil medially. It is less likely to cause posterior pharyngeal swelling. Option (D) Ludwig’s Angina: Ludwig’s angina is a bilateral, rapidly spreading cellulitis of the submandibular space. It is usually caused by dental infections and presents with tender, firm swelling of the floor of the mouth and neck, trismus, and difficulty handling secretions. It does not cause posterior pharyngeal swelling or an increased retropharyngeal space on X-ray.

choices.text: Staphylococcus aureus is the common organism

questions.text: All are true about Ludwig’s angina except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Staphylococcus aureus is the common organism – This statement is false, making it the correct answer to the “except” question. Ludwig’s angina is typically caused by a polymicrobial infection, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria. The most common organisms are Streptococcus viridans (from oral flora) and anaerobes such as Bacteroides and Fusobacterium. While Staphylococcus aureus can be present, it is not the most common or typical causative organism, so this option is not true about Ludwig’s angina. Incorrect options: A. Trismus is a feature – This is true, although it is not one of the most common or primary features. Trismus (difficulty opening the mouth) can occur due to spread of infection to the muscles of mastication or due to pain and inflammation, especially in advanced cases. While not the hallmark symptom, it is still considered a possible feature of Ludwig’s angina. B. Tracheostomy may be required – This is true. Due to the risk of airway compromise from swelling of the floor of the mouth and tongue, airway management is a critical concern. In severe cases where intubation is difficult or impossible, a tracheostomy may be necessary to secure the airway. C. Submandibular space infection – This is true. Ludwig’s angina is classically defined as a bilateral cellulitis involving the submandibular, submental, and sublingual spaces. Infection in these spaces causes the swelling and potential airway obstruction characteristic of the condition.

questions.text: Quinsy is collection of pus in the peritonsillar space b/t capsule of tonsil and :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Superior constrictor. Quinsy, or peritonsillar abscess, is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space, which lies between the capsule of the palatine tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle of the pharynx. It commonly occurs as a complication of acute tonsillitis, particularly when the infection spreads beyond the tonsillar capsule into the surrounding soft tissues. This leads to the classic presentation of fever, severe throat pain (often unilateral), trismus (difficulty opening the mouth), and a "hot potato" voice due to oropharyngeal swelling. Incorrect Options: (B) Middle constrictor – Incorrect: The middle pharyngeal constrictor muscle is located below the superior constrictor and is not directly involved in the formation of a peritonsillar abscess. It plays a role in swallowing by aiding pharyngeal constriction but is anatomically separate from the peritonsillar space. (C) Inferior constrictor – Incorrect: The inferior pharyngeal constrictor is even further down in the pharynx, playing a role in swallowing by assisting in esophageal opening. It is not involved in the peritonsillar space, making it an incorrect answer. (D) Stylohyoid – Incorrect: The stylohyoid muscle is a part of the suprahyoid muscle group and is primarily involved in elevating the hyoid bone and assisting in swallowing. It is not part of the peritonsillar space and does not contribute to the formation of a peritonsillar abscess.

questions.text: Space of the neck most often involved with head and neck infections is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Parapharyngeal space. The parapharyngeal space is the most commonly involved deep neck space in head and neck infections. This space extends from the skull base to the hyoid bone and is divided into anterior (prestyloid) and posterior (poststyloid) compartments. It is in close proximity to the pharynx, tonsils, and teeth, making it highly susceptible to infections spreading from tonsillitis, pharyngitis, dental infections, or peritonsillar abscesses. Due to its anatomical connections with other deep neck spaces, infections in the parapharyngeal space can rapidly spread to the retropharyngeal space and even the mediastinum, leading to serious complications like Lemierre’s syndrome or descending necrotizing mediastinitis. Incorrect Options: (A) Submaxillary space – Incorrect: The submaxillary space (or submandibular space) is located beneath the mandible and is often involved in infections arising from the second and third molars, such as Ludwig’s angina. However, it is not the most commonly affected space in general head and neck infections. (B) Submental space – Incorrect: The submental space lies under the chin, between the anterior bellies of the digastric muscles. It is involved in infections originating from the mandibular incisors but is not the most commonly involved space in general head and neck infections. (D) Retropharyngeal space – Incorrect: The retropharyngeal space extends from the skull base to the mediastinum and is involved in deep neck infections, especially in children. While it can become infected, it is less commonly affected than the parapharyngeal space. However, infections in this space can be very dangerous as they can spread downward into the chest.

questions.text: A 2 year old child presents to emergency with fever and respiratory distress. He has drooling of saliva and her mother told he has been refusing feeds since yesterday. Xray soft tissue neck lateral view is shown in picture. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Retropharyngeal Space - Between the buccopharyngeal fascia covering the pharyngeal constrictor & the prevertebral fascia * Extends from base of skull to bifurcation of trachea * Divided by a fibrous raphe into 2 (spaces of Gilette) * Abscess causes U/L bulge on post pharyngeal wall Acute retropharyngeal abscess - Commonly seen in children < 3yrs * Results of suppuration of retropharyngeal LN * In adults - from penetrating injury of post. pharyngeal wall C/F : * Dysphagia & difficulty in breathing (prominent symp) * Stridor & croupy cough * Torticollis * Bulge in post. Pharyngeal wall (usually seen on one side of midline) Xray STN lat. view - widening of prevertebral shadow T/t - I & D without GA, antibiotics
